bestBHT.bht: In regard to the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ and our gathering together unto Him, we beseech you, brethren, not to be troubled or shaken in mind. The final gathering together of the saints dispels our instinctive fears of judgment. Paul's use of different terms for the Second Coming - παρουσια, επιφανεια, and αποκαλυψις - emphasize the presence, power, and purpose of Christ. Paul is referring to the rapture mentioned in 1 Thessalonians 4:15-17 and the prospect of being forever with the Lord. We should eagerly anticipate that glorious meeting and sight.

Henry Alford: But (passing from those things which he prays for them, to those which he prays of them) we beseech you, brethren (to win their affectionate attention), in regard of the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ..."
It is best therefore to take it as above; with a slight tinge of the meaning 'on behalf of:' for the subject had been misrepresented, and justice is done to it by the Apostle."
the gathering together of us, announced in 1 Thess. iv. 17, to Him.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: The consummating or final gathering together of the saints..."
Our instinctive fears of the judgment are dispelled by the thought of being gathered together UNTO HIM...
Albert Barnes: In regard to that great event of which I spoke to you in my former epistle - the coming of the Saviour - I beseech you not to be troubled, as if it were soon to happen.
As his views had been misunderstood or misrepresented, he now proposes to show them that there was nothing in the true doctrine which should create alarm, as if he were about to appear.
In reference to our being gathered unto him, I beseech you not to be shaken in mind, as if that event were near.
Marvin Vincent: By the coming [υπερ] . More correctly touching."
Uper never in N. T. in a formula of swearing."
Gathering together [επισυναγωγης] . Only here and Hebrews 10:25.
John Calvin: As you set a high value on the coming of Christ, when he will gather us to himself...so I earnestly beseech you by his coming not to be too credulous, should any one affirm, on whatever pretext, that his day is at hand.

For when any day is said to be near, if it does not quickly arrive, mankind being naturally impatient of longer delay, their spirits begin to languish, and that languishing is followed up shortly afterwards by despair.

This was not the design of Lactantius, but Satan, in accordance with his subtlety, perverted his curiosity, and that of those like him, so as to leave nothing in religion definite or fixed, and even at the present day he does not cease to employ the same means.
Philip Schaff: The coming of Christ had been misrepresented; Paul now does it justice by setting it in a clearer light.
Our gathering together. That is, the gathering together of all Christians to be forever with Christ.
The gathering together of all Christians to be forever with Christ, spoken of in the First Epistle, 1 Thessalonians 4:17.
Archibald T. Robertson: For the distinction between Παρουσια, Επιφανεια (Epiphany), and Αποκαλυψις (Revelation) as applied to the Second Coming of Christ...

Παρουσια lays emphasis on the presence of the Lord with his people, επιφανεια on his manifestation of the power and love of God, αποκαλυψις on the revelation of God's purpose and plan in the Second Coming of the Lord Jesus.
Paul is referring to the rapture, mentioned in 1 Thessalonians 4:15-17, and the being forever with the Lord thereafter.
John Gill: the doctrine of Christ's coming, as to the time of it, in its proper light
the coming to judge the quick and dead, than which nothing is more sure and certain

the gathering together of all the elect of God; and so the Arabic version reads, 'the gathering of us all'; and which, as it is certain, is greatly to be desired; it will be a happy meeting and a glorious sight
John Wesley: Our gathering together to him — In the clouds.

bhtAttempts.bht: In regard to the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ and our gathering together unto Him, we beseech you, brethren, not to be troubled or shaken in mind. The Apostle Paul emphasizes the final gathering together of the saints and dispels our instinctive fears of judgment by focusing on being gathered unto Him. The different terms used to describe the Second Coming of Christ - παρουσια, επιφανεια, and αποκαλυψις - highlight the presence of the Lord, His manifestation of power and love, and the revelation of God's purpose. Paul is referring to the rapture mentioned in 1 Thessalonians 4:15-17 and the prospect of being forever with the Lord. Therefore, we should not be credulous or easily swayed by claims about the nearness of His coming, but eagerly anticipate that glorious meeting and sight. The gathering together to Him is our hope and joy.
